It's fun crawling through the rubble that remains from the weirdness in the RSS world 20 or so years ago.

In hindsight -- the attempts to take over RSS failed.

Mostly they were not well thought-out imho.

RSS is massive. You can't even influence it much less take it over.

subs.text:
# The default place-of-record for writers

I would love to see a university-based open source project to create a Medium-like service, run as a non-profit, written and maintained by students, with the help of teachers of course, funded by foundations and contributors.
subs.rawText:
# The default place-of-record for writers

I would love to see a university-based open source project to create a Medium-like service, run as a non-profit, written and maintained by students, with the help of teachers of course, funded by foundations and contributors.

subs.text: The mistake we keep making is relying VCs to create a simple default place-of-record for writing on the internet. Medium has a great user interface, but because they had to find an elusive business model, it kept changing what it was.
subs.rawText: The mistake we keep making is relying VCs to create a simple default place-of-record for writing on the internet. Medium has a great user interface, but because they had to find an elusive business model, it kept changing what it was.

subs.text: I honestly don't think it's possible to create a default place-of-record for writing with a business model attached.
subs.rawText: I honestly don't think it's possible to create a default place-of-record for writing with a business model attached.

subs.text: The university that took this project on would have a long-term source of project funding, and their students would learn more than computer science, they'd learn how to create and support a real world system that means something.
subs.rawText: The university that took this project on would have a long-term source of project funding, and their students would learn more than computer science, they'd learn how to create and support a real world system that means something.

subs.text: And if I recall correctly college students are often searching for that kind of experience, to do meaningful work with their talents.

subs.text:
# Two-way RSS

I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year, specifically RSS going in both directions. Apps that can read RSS and also write RSS.
subs.rawText:
# Two-way RSS

I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year, specifically RSS going in both directions. Apps that can read RSS and also write RSS.

subs.text: As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like [Substack]([link]) only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.
subs.rawText: As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like [Substack](https://t.co/MCOiYl6ihr) only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.

subs.text: But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.
subs.rawText: But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.

subs.text: Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool.  It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.
subs.rawText: Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool.  It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.

subs.text:
Someday we'll look back on this practice and think how could we have missed something so obvious. 
I've asked writers who use Substack how they feel about this, with mixed results. None of the writers are thinking about it very much, apparently.

subs.text:
I was taught that America is a great country. 

1. By the education system, which was wrong. 

2. By my family -- who had good cause to feel America is great, because they took us in during the war, if they hadn't my family would have died. 

But I'm beginning to lose the faith.
subs.rawText:
I was taught that America is a great country. 

1. By the education system, which was wrong. 

2. By my family -- who had good cause to feel America is great, because they took us in during the war, if they hadn't my family would have died. 

But I'm beginning to lose the faith.

subs.text:
A country isn't great because it says it's great. 

A great country does what the Bill of Rights says, but for every citizen, and not for fictitious citizens like corporations.
subs.rawText:
A country isn't great because it says it's great.

subs.text: 1/6 I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year.
subs.rawText: 1/6 I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year.

subs.text: 2/6 As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like Substack only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.
subs.rawText: 2/6 As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like Substack only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.

subs.text: 3/6 But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.
subs.rawText: 3/6 But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.

subs.text: 4/6 Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool. It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.
subs.rawText: 4/6 Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool. It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.

subs.text: i spent a lot of years learning how to do software demos, and then how to design software to demo well. it's important, otherwise your ideas and what you learn exist in a vacuum, and can't influence anyone.
subs.rawText: i spent a lot of years learning how to do software demos, and then how to design software to demo well. it's important, otherwise your ideas and what you learn exist in a vacuum, and can't influence anyone.

subs.text: i know what it's like to be an expert in abstractions, that's what i am -- but you have to make it real for people who aren't experts and don't think in abstractions.
subs.rawText: i know what it's like to be an expert in abstractions, that's what i am -- but you have to make it real for people who aren't experts and don't think in abstractions.

subs.text: then you test your demos with real people. see if they get anything from your demo. let them ask questions, if they don't have any the demo didn't work. if their questions have nothing to do with what you demoed it didn't work.
subs.rawText: then you test your demos with real people. see if they get anything from your demo. let them ask questions, if they don't have any the demo didn't work. if their questions have nothing to do with what you demoed it didn't work.

subs.text: how many demos have you seen where the demoer spends the first 10 minutes talking before doing any demoing? the demo begins immediately (unless you're steve jobs in his prime, when you get to tease).
subs.rawText: how many demos have you seen where the demoer spends the first 10 minutes talking before doing any demoing? the demo begins immediately (unless you're steve jobs in his prime, when you get to tease).

subs.text: and you practice relentlessly, so when it finally comes time to do the big demo you could do it in your dreams.
